items.text: **Richard John Beattie Seaman** (4 February 1913 – 25 June 1939), was one of the greatest pre-war [[LINK|lang_en|Grand_Prix_motor_racing|Grand Prix]] drivers from Britain. He famously drove for the [[LINK|lang_en|Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes-Benz]] team from 1937–1939 in the [[LINK|lang_en|Mercedes-Benz_W154|Mercedes-Benz W154]] car, winning the 1938 [[LINK|lang_en|German_Grand_Prix|German Grand Prix]]. He died of his injuries after his car crashed into a tree and caught fire during the [[LINK|lang_en|1939_Belgian_Grand_Prix|1939 Belgian Grand Prix]]. [[CITE||undefined]]

Seaman was born in [[LINK|lang_en|Chichester|Chichester]], [[LINK|lang_en|Sussex|Sussex]] to William John Beattie-Seaman in a wealthy family and initially lived at [[LINK|lang_en|Kentwell_Hall|Kentwell Hall]], Long Melford in Suffolk, developing an enthusiasm for motoring from his childhood. After studying at [[LINK|lang_en|Rugby_School|Rugby School]] and  [[LINK|lang_en|Trinity_College,_Cambridge|Trinity College, Cambridge]],[[CITE|2|https://openlibrary.org/search?q=%22Obituary%3A%20Mr%20Richard%20Seaman%22.%20*The%20Times*.%2027%20Jun]] in 1934 he resolved to become a racing driver and took his [[LINK|lang_en|MG_Cars|MG]] car to the European mainland to gain experience. He won the [[LINK|lang_en|Voiturette|Voiturette]] race of the [[LINK|lang_en|Swiss_Grand_Prix|Swiss Grand Prix]] event at [[LINK|lang_en|Circuit_Bremgarten|Bremgarten]] at his first attempt. He won other small races for [[LINK|lang_en|English_Racing_Automobiles|English Racing Automobiles]] (ERA) He was very successful in the 1936 season both in UK and on the Continent using a 1926 1500 cc Delage race car which was developed  and modified to be almost unbeatable at the time with Dick Seaman driving and eventually Mercedes team chief [[LINK|lang_en|Alfred_Neubauer|Alfred Neubauer]] invited him for a trial at the [[LINK|lang_en|N%C3%BCrburgring|Nürburgring]]. Both [[LINK|lang_en|Silver_Arrows|Silver Arrows]] teams used to have at least one foreign driver, if available. [[CITE||undefined]]

In 1937 he signed for [[LINK|lang_en|Mercedes-Benz|Mercedes-Benz]] against the wishes of his mother, who did not want him to drive for a "[[LINK|lang_en|Nazism|Nazi]]" team. The Mercedes (and their rival Auto Union) cars, which were part of a racing program that was German government subsidized were far faster, better financed, better built, more advanced and more reliable than any of the racing cars he had driven previously. He now had a chance to win Grands Prix and be one of the top drivers in the European Grand Prix championship. Having a solid start to his career with Mercedes in 1937, he excelled in the 1938 season – he won the 1938 [[LINK|lang_en|German_Grand_Prix|German Grand Prix]], giving the [[LINK|lang_en|Nazi_salute|Nazi salute]] on the podium and becoming one of the favourite drivers of [[LINK|lang_en|Adolf_Hitler|Adolf Hitler]],[[CITE|3|http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0,6903,782811,00.html]] and came second in the 1938 [[LINK|lang_en|Swiss_Grand_Prix|Swiss Grand Prix]]. In December 1938 he married Erica Popp, the daughter of the director of [[LINK|lang_en|BMW|BMW]], again against his mother's wishes.

Leading the 1939 [[LINK|lang_en|Belgian_Grand_Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]] at [[LINK|lang_en|Circuit_de_Spa-Francorchamps|Spa-Francorchamps]] during a wet race, Seaman crashed his car into a tree during lap 22. It is thought he was using a line through a corner that was only normally used in the dry. After the impact, the car caught fire, with the unconscious driver still inside. Seaman died a few hours later as a result of his burns, at just 26 years of age; it was Mercedes' only fatality during that time. On his death bed he remarked to the Mercedes chief engineer, "I was going too fast for the conditions – it was entirely my own fault. I am sorry".[[CITE|3|http://observer.guardian.co.uk/osm/story/0,6903,782811,00.html]]

After Seaman's death, Mercedes-Benz dealerships worldwide were ordered to display his photograph in their windows. Richard Seaman was buried at [[LINK|lang_en|Putney_Vale_Cemetery|Putney Vale Cemetery]] in London.

caption.text: Dick Seaman's grave at [[LINK|lang_en|Putney_Vale_Cemetery|Putney Vale Cemetery]], London in 2014

sentences.text: [[LINK|lang_en|1935_Grand_Prix_Season|1935]]: DNF Frontieres GP, [[LINK|lang_en|Eifelrennen|Eifelrennen]] (Voiturette) (4), [[LINK|lang_en|Coppa_Acerbo|Coppa Acerbo]] (Voiturette) (1), [[LINK|lang_en|Swiss_Grand_Prix|Swiss Grand Prix]] (Voiturette) (1), [[LINK|lang_en|Czech_Grand_Prix|Czech Grand Prix]] (Voiturette) (1)

[[LINK|lang_en|1936_Grand_Prix_Season|1936]]: British Empire Trophy (Handicap) (1), [[LINK|lang_en|Isle_of_Man|Isle of Man]] (Voiturette) (1), [[LINK|lang_en|German_Grand_Prix|German Grand Prix]] (8), [[LINK|lang_en|Coppa_Ciano|Coppa Ciano]] (Voiturette) (6), [[LINK|lang_en|Coppa_Acerbo|Coppa Acerbo]] (Voiturette) (1), DNF [[LINK|lang_en|Coppa_Acerbo|Coppa Acerbo]], [[LINK|lang_en|Swiss_Grand_Prix|Swiss Grand Prix]] (Voiturette) (1), JCC 200 Miles (Voiturette) (1), [[LINK|lang_en|Donington_Grand_Prix|Donington Grand Prix]] (1)

[[LINK|lang_en|1937_Grand_Prix_Season|1937]]: [[LINK|lang_en|Tripoli_Grand_Prix|Tripoli Grand Prix]] (7), [[LINK|lang_en|AVUS|AVUS]] Grand Prix (5), DNF [[LINK|lang_en|Eifelrennen|Eifelrennen]] GP, [[LINK|lang_en|Vanderbilt_Cup|Vanderbilt Cup]] (2), DNF [[LINK|lang_en|German_Grand_Prix|German Grand Prix]], [[LINK|lang_en|Coppa_Acerbo|Coppa Acerbo]] (5), [[LINK|lang_en|1937_Italian_Grand_Prix|1937 Italian Grand Prix]] (4), [[LINK|lang_en|1937_Czechoslovakian_Grand_Prix|1937 Czechoslovakian Grand Prix]] (4), DNF [[LINK|lang_en|1937_Donington_Grand_Prix|1937 Donington Grand Prix]] Donington

[[LINK|lang_en|1938_Grand_Prix_season|1938]]: DNS [[LINK|lang_en|French_Grand_Prix|French Grand Prix]], [[LINK|lang_en|German_Grand_Prix|German Grand Prix]] (1), [[LINK|lang_en|Swiss_Grand_Prix|Swiss Grand Prix]] (2), DNF [[LINK|lang_en|Italian_Grand_Prix|Italian Grand Prix]], [[LINK|lang_en|Donington_Grand_Prix|Donington Grand Prix]] (3)

[[LINK|lang_en|1939_Grand_Prix_season|1939]]: DNS [[LINK|lang_en|Pau_Grand_Prix|Pau Grand Prix]], DNF [[LINK|lang_en|Eifelrennen|Eifelrennen]] GP, DNF [[LINK|lang_en|Belgian_Grand_Prix|Belgian Grand Prix]]
